node.title: If solar is now so cheap, why is my power bill still so high?
node.alt: Solar panels extend to the horizon
node.description: After years of increases, power prices are set to fall, thanks largely to cheap solar.Â So how cheap can solar get? And what does this mean for your electricity bill?
node.content:
["After a long decade of year-on-year increases in power prices throughout the country, the cost of electricity is forecast to fall in most places.", "How far it falls \u2014 and how quickly \u2014\u00a0depends on lots of factors, but there's clear consensus that Australia is entering a new era in which power will be cheaper than it has ever been before.", "In two years,\u00a0renewables have gone from economic\u00a0\"wrecking ball\"\u00a0to the technology that will unlock future green industries, with the Prime Minister recently\u00a0setting\u00a0a target of \"ultra-low cost solar\" by 2035.", "", "
The government hopes cheap solar will make viable\u00a0new low-carbon energy-intensive industries such as green hydrogen and green steel.(Supplied: Neoen )
", "There's even talk in some quarters\u00a0that solar\u00a0could one day\u00a0fulfil the unrealised promise of nuclear power\u00a0to generate\u00a0electricity so abundant that it would be\u00a0\"too cheap to meter\".", "So how cheap can solar get?\u00a0And will you \u2014\u00a0the energy consumer \u2014\u00a0still have a power bill?", "
'Glimpse of the future' as power prices go negative
", "This future of cheap power is already here \u2014\u00a0at least sometimes.", "Last Saturday\u00a0in South Australia, renewables accounted for a staggering\u00a0135\u00a0per cent of total demand, breaking the world record for the\u00a0proportion\u00a0of solar and\u00a0wind supplied to a\u00a0large grid.", "As a result of all this excess generation, the spot price of power fell to\u00a0minus $35.95 per megawatt hour.", "Energy generation was curtailed, batteries charged up, and the excess exported to Victoria, which is connected to the SA grid.", "\"It's a glimpse of the future,\" says Frank Jotzo, a professor of climate change economics at Australian National University (ANU).", "The decline in electricity\u00a0prices is largely thanks to new solar, wind and battery\u00a0projects coming online, according to the Australian Energy Market Commission (AEMC) in a recent report.", "Among renewables, solar dominates, and it's expected\u00a0this trend will\u00a0continue over the next decade, with solar (including rooftop PV) to account for more than half of generation by 2030.", "
The price of solar has fallen faster than expectations
", "In May this year, the University of New South Wales's (UNSW) Martin Green, a\u00a0legendary figure\u00a0in the development of low-cost solar, made a startling\u00a0prediction: the cents-per-watt price of solar modules will halve\u00a0by 2023.", "\"One of my colleagues has called it 'insanely cheap electricity',\" he said at the time.", "He predicted this\u00a0would result in power purchase agreements (PPAs, or the price at which a supplier agrees to sell electricity over a fixed period of time)\u00a0of $10 per megawatt hour (MWh).", "", "
Professor Green\u00a0co-developed\u00a0the technology that's used in most solar cells around the world.(Supplied: UNSW)
", "To put this in context, the average wholesale price of electricity in NSW in 2021-22 was $72/MWh, with PPAs for solar at about $40-$50/MWh.", "Professor Green's forecast even outpaces\u00a0the\u00a0Prime Minister's target for \"ultra-low cost solar\" of $15/MWh by 2035.", "So it's a bold claim, but the price of solar has consistently fallen faster than expectations, due largely to three factors:", "Since May, Professor Green has had to revise his forecast because supply-chain disruptions due to COVID and\u00a0a string of explosions at factories in China\u00a0have led to unexpected cost increases.", "\"We're now looking like we'll reach those prices towards the end of the decade, instead of the middle of the decade,\" he said.", "
With solar this cheap, what will my power bills be?
", "This is where it gets a bit more complicated.", "There's a big difference between the wholesale price of power, which is the price the retailers pay the\u00a0suppliers, and the retail price.", "It takes time for the benefit of low wholesale prices to flow through to consumers, says Renate Egan,\u00a0a professor at UNSW and head of the\u00a0Australian Centre for Advanced Photovoltaics.", "\"But it does flow through.", "One reason cheaper generation doesn't entirely flow through to consumers is the cost of building transmission links to new renewables projects, as well as adding storage\u00a0(big batteries or pumped hydro).", "The storage is necessary to \"firm\" the grid,\u00a0so that stored energy can be used when renewables cannot meet demand.", "This cost will increase as renewables contribute a greater share to total generation.", "", "
The influx of renewables is stretching the country's outdated network of transmission lines(ABC News: Michael Barnett)
", "A 2020 CSIRO analysis estimated\u00a0transmission and storage would add $23/MWh to the cost of solar and wind, in a scenario where renewables\u00a0accounted for 90 per cent of generation by 2030.", "If that's the case, transmitting and storing electrons across the grid could soon cost more than generating them from solar panels.", "Household energy consumers\u00a0would still be paying for mains electricity (the equation changes if you have your own solar panels), but probably less than before \u2014\u00a0at least in the short term.", "The AEMC's recent report forecast a modest $77 average national drop in annual bills\u00a0by 2024.", "That's not much, but at least they're going down.", "\"We expect the fall in price to follow a sawtooth pattern,\" Professor Jotzo said.", "
Could savvy households end up paying nothing for mains power?
", "In the longer term, it might be possible for households to effectively pay nothing to import power from the grid.", "Denis Scanlon's\u00a0energy set-up is an\u00a0example of\u00a0the ways households may\u00a0consume, generate and trade electricity in the future.", "His rural property outside Adelaide has solar panels, a storage battery, and a \"smart inverter\" that's remotely controlled by his electricity retailer.", "", "
Smart inverters mean the vast and disorganised network of rooftop solar panels can be operated like one solar farm.(Supplied: Denis Scanlon)
", "Most homes have a \"smart meter\" that tracks the amount of electricity the\u00a0home consumes; a smart inverter is a step beyond that.", "When power prices went negative in South Australia last Saturday, Mr Scanlon's retailer used the smart inverter to stop his panels\u00a0exporting power to avoid overloading the grid, which can cause rolling blackouts.", "\"They don't\u00a0want every rooftop to be exporting,\" Mr Scanlon said.", "\"The smart inverter allows them to isolate and take generation out of the system.\"", "", "
This graph shows solar production (green) plunging just before midday, when Mr Scanlon's rooftop panels were switched off.
", "Mr Scanlon also has a new kind of electricity contract where he pays the wholesale price, rather than the retail one.\u00a0", "The wholesale price fluctuates in response to\u00a0cloud cover or wind speed, or gas generators coming online, and he tracks\u00a0prices, generation, storage, and consumption\u00a0from his phone.", "As you might guess, it's easy to lose yourself in watching the market.", "If Mr Scanlon allowed it to, the retailer could also use the smart inverter to turn\u00a0off his energy-intensive appliances, like the air conditioner\u00a0or the pool pump, in response to increases\u00a0in the price of electricity.", "All these gizmos add up to a new kind of relationship between the energy consumers, retailers,\u00a0the grid, and the generators.", "Instead of paying a standard monthly bill for access to electricity generated at a\u00a0central power station, households\u00a0will have the opportunity to be minor electricity moguls, taking advantage of negative price events, such as the one in South Australia last Saturday.", "A fully charged\u00a0electrical vehicle battery\u00a0can power a standard home for three days, so with the right charging infrastructure, households could conceivably scoop up vast amounts of free power a few times a week and get away with paying nothing the rest of the time.", "\"I'm happy to keep refining our energy consumption,\" Mr Scanlon said.", "
I don't own a house:\u00a0what do I do?
", "But what about everyone\u00a0who doesn't own their own house, or can't afford a battery?", "In this brave new world, many people won't have the capital or the technical knowledge to take advantage of low power prices, says\u00a0Declan Kuch, a researcher at Western Sydney University who has been looking into the social impact of cheaper electricity.", "\"There are very clear equity issues coming up,\" he says.", "He's wary of\u00a0a utopian narrative of \"magical tech\" coordinating batteries, panels and appliances across a decentralised\u00a0grid.", "\"That's a bit of a furphy,\" he said.", "\"Centralised agencies will be needed to maintain the system and have the energy reliability that we take for granted.\"", "Instead, he foresees the \"remunicipalisation\" of energy, meaning that local councils and community groups will increasingly offer energy retail services (there are already some examples of this).", "\"We're seeing new kinds of collective action that are not motivated by getting the lowest price, but motivated by coming together and often solving climate change issues,\" he said.", "\"They have a very different vision to, 'Let's\u00a0try and make as much money as possible.''\"", "", "
Household power bills expected to fall in coming years
", "
How cheap could solar get longer term?
", "If wholesale electricity prices could go as low as $10/MWh by 2030 or 2035, what's the forecast for beyond that?", "This is partly a question of solar module efficiency, UNSW's Professor Green says.", "The standard silicon solar cell converts about 18-22 per cent of incoming solar energy\u00a0into electricity.", "Solar panels of 40 per cent efficiency can be reached\u00a0by stacking cells of different materials on top of each other; the composite cell can convert different wavelengths of light more efficiently.", "", "
Solar panels made from substances other than silicon could one day be cheaper, lighter and more efficient.(Supplied: Monash University)
", "For the moment, however, cells made this way are wildly expensive.", "\"That's what lies further down the track \u2014\u00a0stacking cells on top of each other,\" Professor Green said."]
